question: Baby bye-bye...
answer: Hey, come back! You heard what your mother said!

question: ignores Roger. We FOLLOW HIM as he crawls into the kitchen. He stops to regard something that has caught his attention... a cookie jar. It's sitting on top of the refrigerator. Coo-kie. is swinging precariously on the door of the freeer.
answer: Hang on, Baby. I'll save you!

question: Starting tomorrow there'll be no more roast beef lunches. What happened to cheese sandwiches? I was raised on cheese sandwiches. And tell that guy sleepin' over there he's fired! Oh... tell him he's promoted. But get him out of my sight. Valiant, did you see the rabbit?
answer: He was blowin' his lines, all right. So what?

question: So what? He's already put me three weeks behind on the shooting schedule! No! That's not funny. That's funny. Put a homburg on him it'll even be funnier. Huh, Valiant?
answer: Yeah, that'd be a riot.

question: Boy, I hope what you have ain't contagious or I'll be out of business. How much do you know about show business, Valiant?
answer: Only there's no business like it, no business I know.

question: Yeah, and there's no business as expensive. I'm twenty-five grand over budget on the latest Bunnysitter cartoon and it's all because that rabbit can't keep his mind on his work. And you know why?
answer: One too many safes dropped on his head?

question: Nah, that goes with the territory. He's a stunt bunny. Here's the problem... "Seen cooing over calamari with notsonew Sugar Daddy was Jessica Rabbit... wife of Maroon star, Roger". His wife's a tramp, but he thinks she's Betty Crocker. The doubt's eatin' him up.
answer: So what do you want me to do?

question: Get me a couple juicy pictures. Somethin' I can wise the rabbit up with.
answer: I don't work in Toontown.

question: You don't have to. The rabbit's wife sings at an underground Toon revue joint called The Ink & Paint Club. You can catch her in action there.
answer: The job's gonna cost you a hundred bucks.

question: A hundred bucks? That's ridiculous.
answer: So's the job.

question: All right, all right... You got your hundred bucks. Fifty now, fifty when you deliver the pictures. Kinda jumpy aren't you, Valiant? It's just Dumbo. I got him on loan from Disney.
answer: Aren't you the lucky one...

question: When will I hear from you?
answer: As soon as is humanly possible. Damn Toons. hops off his freeloader's seat on the back, Thanks for the cigarettes. takes the note and walks back across the street toward the terminal. He climbs up a flight of stairs, heading for a bar on the mezzanine. The bar sports a red neon sign that used to blink, "The Terminal Station Bar". But now it just says, "Terminal". enters this den, lets his eyes adjust for a moment, then bellies up to the bar. He finds a spot between a ONE-ARMED BLACK SOLDIER and a MIDGET stretched out on the bar passed out. Now a TROLLEY RUMBLES underneath them. The bar starts to shake like an earthquake, the lights flicker. All the drinkers, observing a time honored ritual, lift their glasses simultaneously to avoid spilling any drops. Even the Midget lifts his head until the trolley has passed. Valiant reaches over the bar and blind-grabs a bottle of rye he obviously knows is there. He pours himself a shot. Hey, fellas, what's the good word? Well, you know what they say about dames, Augie...

question: As soon as is humanly possible. Damn Toons. hops off his freeloader's seat on the back, Thanks for the cigarettes. takes the note and walks back across the street toward the terminal. He climbs up a flight of stairs, heading for a bar on the mezzanine. The bar sports a red neon sign that used to blink, "The Terminal Station Bar". But now it just says, "Terminal". enters this den, lets his eyes adjust for a moment, then bellies up to the bar. He finds a spot between a ONE-ARMED BLACK SOLDIER and a MIDGET stretched out on the bar passed out. Now a TROLLEY RUMBLES underneath them. The bar starts to shake like an earthquake, the lights flicker. All the drinkers, observing a time honored ritual, lift their glasses simultaneously to avoid spilling any drops. Even the Midget lifts his head until the trolley has passed. Valiant reaches over the bar and blind-grabs a bottle of rye he obviously knows is there. He pours himself a shot. Hey, fellas, what's the good word? Well, you know what they say about dames, Augie...
answer: So, makin' dame jokes, huh, Eddie? Well, lemme remind ya pal, it was a dame who took a hundred bucks out of the till so your landlord would't throw you out of your dump. And it was a dame who trusted you for the money when no one else in town would. And it's a dame who's tired of waitin' for you to straighten yourself out and get a job!

question: Would this be the same dame who's going to feel awfully foolish when she finds out I've got her money.
answer: This is fifty bucks. I need seventy-five before they check the books tomorrow.

question: You'll have it in the morning. Now be a sport and lemme have twenty bucks to put in my pocket.
answer: Is this paper even good?

question: Check the scrawl.
answer: R.K. Maroon.

question: He lights a cigarette impassively, not humored by the Toon hijinx. He spots an empty table off to the side and makes his way towards it. A SILLY GEEZER in a loud suit is at the next table. The Geezer nods to him soberly as Valiant pulls Out the chair and sits down. A LOUD FLATULENCE SOUND erupts from under Valiant. The Geezer slaps his thigh with the hilarity of it all.
answer: Will you listen to that? It's a pip! I'm thinking of callin' it a Whoopee Cushion. No hard feelings, I hope. Put 'er there... Hand buzzer... real gasser.

question: Scotch. Just as long as there's no maximum.
answer: Waiter, I'll sign my check now.

question: That's it for you, pops!
answer: Calm down, son. Look, the ink is gone. See? It disappears.

question: Well, why don't you make like the ink?
answer: Gee, it's swell to see you, Eddie. We miss you in Toontown.

question: Wish I could say the same. What're you doin' here, Betty?
answer: Work's been slow for me since the cartoons went to color. But I still got it, Eddie... 'Boop boop be-doop'.

question: Yeah, you still got it, Betty. Who's Mr. Jocularity?
answer: That's Marvin Acme, the gag king.

question: Shoulda guessed.
answer: He comes here every night to see Jessica Rabbit.

question: Big on the musical comedy, huh?
answer: Sounds like you ve never seen her, Eddie.

question: Well, you better start thinkin' about drinkin' it black.
answer: Frankly, I'm shocked. Marvin Acme's been my friend and neighbor for thirty years. Who would have thought he was the Sugar Daddy? Well, the important thing now Roger, is to put all this behind you. Drink this, son, you'll feel better. I know this all seems painful now, but you'll find someone new. Won't he, Mr, Valiant?

question: Oh, yeah. Good lookin' guy like him. Dames'll be breakin' his door down. Son-of-a-bitch... Mr. Maroon, I think I'll be goin' now, so about the rest of my fee...
answer: Sure, Valiant, sure... Being experienced in these matrimonial matters, you have any advice for our friend here?

question: At least he took it well. Lieutenant Santino... how ya doin'?
answer: Tell me you didn't do a snoop job for a Toon named Roger the Rabbit.

question: That's what you woke me up for?
answer: You got trouble, Eddie. Now what?

question: Just haven't been this close to Toontown for awhile.
answer: Let's go, somebody wants to see you. They say the rabbit got the safe idea from a cartoon he was makin' the other day.

question: What a gasser.
answer: Wait here...

question: The rabbit's movements are fairly clear after leaving the Maroon Studios. He ran across the street, jimmied this door open, hoisted the safe on a block and tackle... ... then stood out here waiting for his prey. After he cold-bloodedly accomplished his task, he went home. He was almost apprehended there by my men.
answer: Men? They look more like weasles to me.

question: Yes, I find that weasles have a special gift for the work. The rabbit didn't contact you by any chance, did he?
answer: Why would he contact me? I just took some lousy pictures.

question: So you wouldn't have any idea where he might be?
answer: Have you tried Walla Walla? Kokomo's very nice this time of year.

question: I'm surprised you aren't more cooperative, Mr. Valiant. A human has been murdered by a Toon. Don't you appreciate the magnitude of that? My goal as Judge of Toontown, has been to rein in the insanity. To bring a semblance of law and order to a place where no civilized person has ever been able to step foot. The only way to do that is to make the Toons respect the law.
answer: Judge Doom! Here, let me get that for ya.

question: Why, you filthy little vagrant, you've soiled my robe!
answer: It's cleanin' up real good. Judge.

question: Oh, no, Judge, please, please, lemme go. I think I hear my mother callin' me.
answer: Voltaire... the Gopher!

question: Hey, don't I have any rights?
answer: Yes, you do... to a swift and speedy trial. Court is now in session. The defendant is charged with vagrancy, assault and resisting arrest. How do you find him? Guilty as charged. Case closed! I hereby sentence you to the dip!

question: Hey, Eddie, looks like you really stepped in it this time.
answer: What are you complaining about? Here's your fifty bucks. What's with Earl?

question: A new outfit bought the Red Car. Some big company called Cloverleaf Industries.
answer: No kiddin'? Bought the Red Cars, huh?

question: Bastards put him on notice.
answer: Here's to the pencil pushers. May they all get lead poisoning.

question: Eddie, get him down from there. He's gonna break his neck.
answer: I know, I know... poor S.O.B.

question: Do you think the rabbit did it?
answer: I don't wanna think. I wanna drink.

question: Make it dry. Baby doesn't like to be wet. You're Valiant, right? The name's Baby Herman.
answer: I know who you are. Kinda out of your neighborhood, aren't you?

question: Yeah, I had to go slummin'. See, a friend of mine's bein' framed.
answer: You mean the rabbit? They got him cold.

question: asleep in the bed.
answer: still with his back to Roger, sits down exhaustedly on the bed and kicks off his shoes. He lies back and pulls the covers over him. He closes his eyes, rolls over to get comfortable. Now he and Roger are nose-to-nose. They both open their eyes at the same time. They freak. Aah!

question: Aah!
answer: What the hell are you doin'?

question: I needed a place to hide. I'm in trouble, Eddie.
answer: So I hear. Even talkin' to you could get me a rap for aiding and abetting.

question: Don't worry, Eddie, no one knows I'm here.
answer: Oh, yeah? Then how'd you find my house?

question: Well, I asked the newsboy on the corner. He didn't know. Then I asked a janitor, the fireman and finally the green grocer down the way. He was very helpful.
answer: In other words, the whole goddamn world knows you're here! Out! Get out!

question: Please, Eddie, don't put me out. I didn't do it, I swear. Sure I wanted to win Jessy back, but not that way. After I left you, I went to see her at the Ink & Paint Club. She was on stage, so I found a piece of paper and wrote her a love letter. 'Dear Jessy. How do I love thee? Let me count the ways. 1-1000, 2-1000, Hey, that wasn't very nice. It took me almost an hour to compose that. But I decided not to leave it anyway. I'd read it in person, that was my plan.
answer: Look, pal, if you're still here when I finish this drink, I'm callin' the police.

question: Don't do that! I'm innocent I tell ya. The police'll just dip me. They were waitin' for me when I got home last night. I ran.
answer: If you're so innocent, why'd you run?

question: Gee, Eddie, I'm a rabbit. We always run.
answer: That's it.

question: Well, this is the moment of truth! And I've spoken the truth, but you won't believe the truth. So I guess the truth is my goose is cooked, my hash is slung. my fait is accompli. Won't anything change your mind?
answer: The goddamn will.

question: You mean you believe me? It's Toon Control!
answer: Get away from that window.

question: You're gonna help me? How can I ever thank you?
answer: For starters... don't ever kiss me. I'll talk to 'em. Find a place to hide. Not in there. That's the first place they'll look.

question: Eddie Valiant... you're under arrest! Just kidding...
answer: You idiot. I lost the key for those cuffs.

question: I oughta have my head examined. Will you hold still?
answer: Does this help?

question: Yeah, that's better. You mean to tell me you coulda taken your hand outta that cuff at any time?
answer: Well, no, not any time. Only when it was funny.

question: Are you always this funny, or only on days when you're wanted for murder?
answer: My philosophy is if you don't have a sense of humor, you're better off dead.

question: Maybe Baby Herman was right. Somebody wants Acme's property. Cack the old man, pin it on Roger, and destroy the will.
answer: The habeus corpus is thickening.

question: Yeah. Except they screwed up. I don't think they got the will.
answer: How do you know that?

question: Nothin', no one, nowhere,
answer: Maybe money grows on trees in Toontown, but not at the Maroon Studio.

question: This'll be fine, huh, Augie? Forget about the prices, pal. If you want the shrimp cocktail, you have a shrimp cocktail. Excuse me, Augie, I've got a little table-hopping to do.
answer: Trying to scare up a bidding war between me and Jack Warner, eh? Well, it won't work. I'll call William Morris and I'll have 'em put out a rabbit call the likes of which this town's never seen! And stop callin' me Doc!

question: Hi, Mr. Maroon. Remember me?
answer: Valiant? What're you doin' here?

question: I Just thought I'd drop by and show you a photograph.
answer: I've already seen your photographs.

question: Yeah, but I enlarged this one. Thought you might be interested. Anyway... enjoy your lunch. How is that, Augie, pretty good? It's me. Valiant says there's a will. I don't know what he's trying to pull... Somebody's gonna have to take care of him. The old man had it at the club that night. That's right. Yeah, I'm sure. I'll be there. Where? Iris... cancel my appointments this afternoon. I'll be at Forest Lawn. You did great, Augie. Have another shrimp cocktail. Love that Red Car.
answer: So... trying to pull a fast one on me, huh?

question: These are bold accusations, Mr. Valiant. I hope you have some proof?
answer: I found the cover the will came in behind the dressing table. They must've taken it off me.

question: They?
answer: The other people who were in here lookin' for the will. I woulda caught 'em if Cheetah here hadn't interrupted me.

question: Take it easy, Bongo. We'll handle Mr. Valiant our own way... downtown.
answer: Downtown? Fine. Get a hold of Santino, I'd be more than glad to talk to him.

question: Oh, not that downtown. Toontown.
answer: You're not takin' me to downtown Toontown?

question: Indeed we are. We'll continue the interrogation there.
answer: I ain't tellin' you nothin'! Get me Santino.

question: You're a very stubborn man, Mr. Valiant. Very pig-headed. Boys, show Mr. Valiant how we handle pig-headed men at the Toontown station...
answer: No... you bastards! Leggo of me!

question: Here's one for the books... a Toon wearin' human clothes.
answer: Earl... it's me, Valiant.

question: Eddie? Jesus, what happened?
answer: Toon cops worked me over.

question: Boy, I'll say. They gave you a real Toon-a-Roo.
answer: What am I, Earl?

question: You're a pig... a happy-go-lucky pig.
answer: No...

question: Does it hurt?
answer: Not much. It's hard to talk.

question: Uh, Eddie, do me a favor. Could you sit in the back so you won't cause as much of a commotion.
answer: Kid, if you hit me on the head, I'm gonna throw you out this window. Dammit!

question: Kid, if you hit me on the head, I'm gonna throw you out this window. Dammit!
answer: Hello, Mr. Valiant. I rang the doorbell, but I guess you couldn't hear it.

question: That's because I don't have a doorbell.
answer: Oh... well, I... I just had to see you.

question: Okay, you've seen me. Now give me a towel.
answer: What's that thing?

question: Come on, lady, haven't you ever seen a mole before?
answer: Toons aren't given imperfections.

question: No? I guess we're not counting lying, stealing and murder.
answer: You've got the wrong idea about me. I'a a pawn in this just like poor Roger. Can you help me find him? I'll pay you anything.

question: Yeah, I'll bet you would. You gotta have the rabbit to make the scam work.
answer: No, no, no... I love my husband.

question: Oh, sure. I can just feature you standin' outside your little hutch, holdin' a carrot cake waitin' for hubby to come home.
answer: Oh, please don't make fun of me, Mr, Valiant. You don't know how hard it is being a woman looking the way I do.

question: Yeah, well, you don't know how hard it is bein' a man looking at a woman looking the way you do.
answer: I'm not bad, I'm just drawn that way.

question: I'm not complainin'. But give me credit. I'm the guy who took the pictures of you and Acme playin' pattycake, remember?
answer: Maroon came to me. He told me he'd fire Roger if I didn't do it. I went along with him for Roger's sake. It was only pattycake, after all.

question: So altruistic.
answer: It's the truth. Why won't you believe it?

question: Cause I don't take Acme Dumb Pills. I don't know what you're up to, lady, but I'm gonna nail you for the Acme murder.
answer: If I'm as bad as you think, what's stopping me from just killing you right now?

question: This cup of turpentine right here. Go for that gun in your purse and I'm gonna let you have it.
answer: Oh, Mr, Valiant, please... you're my only hope. I'm weak... you're strong. Can't you find a place somewhere in your heart to help me?

question: Lemme guess... your cousin from Des Moines?
answer: Perhaps I should go.

question: Must you?
answer: Goodbye, Eddie... don't hate me.

question: What was that?
answer: That was the rabbit's wife.

question: The rabbit's wife? Wanna tell me what she was doin' with her arms around you?
answer: Probably lookin' for a good place to stick a knife.

question: I just stopped by to tell you that I checked out the Acme probate.
answer: Maroon, right?

question: Nope. It's that Cloverleaf outfit again.
answer: What the hell would they want with a gag factory?

question: Got me. But unless the will shows up by Friday midnight, it's theirs.
answer: What's that comin' from the bar?

question: Sounds like singin'.
answer: Oh, no...

question: Oh, no...
answer: 'Things turned out fine And now she's mine...' '... Cause the merry-go-round Went round... Hoo-hoo, Hoo-hoo...' 'My name is Roger Rabbit I've got a crazy habit I like to sing and dance and yuk...' '... So brighten up and smile You schmuck'. Hey, don't I get an encore?

question: Why, you crazy Toon... I've been out there riskin' my neck for you. I come back here and you're singin' and dancin'.
answer: But that's my calling, my purpose, my raison d'etre. Toons are supposed to make people laugh... and believe me, those people needed a laugh.

question: And when they're done laughin' , they're gonna call the cops. That guy Angelo would rat on you for a nickel!
answer: Angelo? He's a pal, a chum...

question: An arsonist and a kidnapper. He just got outta prison.
answer: Well... I still don't think he'd turn me in.

question: Just because you got 'em to laugh?
answer: A laugh can be a powerful thing, Eddie. Sometimes it's the only weapon we have in life.

question: I think I prefer the Smith and Wesson variety.
answer: I've met some cynical and miserable humans in my time. But you, Edward Valiant, are positively funereal!

question: Well, right now it's gonna be your funereal.
answer: Go ahead and throw that punch. But you'd be more successful with a punch line.

question: Reckless driving. Do you believe that?
answer: Hard to imagine.

question: Hold your breath, babies... Hate to sound like Chicken Little, but is the sky falling or what?
answer: Grab it, you idiot! The brakes! The brakes!

question: Forget the brakes, who brought the water wings? Maybe it's my imagination, but I always seem to run better after I've had a wash. Now where can I drop you cats?
answer: Thanks, Benny.

question: If you ever need me, just stick out your thumb.
answer: sticks his key in the door and unlocks it. Roger studies the banner.

question: sticks his key in the door and unlocks it. Roger studies the banner.
answer: Valiant and Valiant? Who's the other Valiant?

question: My brother. Get inside.
answer: So what's our plan, our scenario, our modus operandi?

question: We can't do anything till it's dark.
answer: Guess you haven't been here in a while. 'Japs Bomb Pearl Harbor'. Say, who's this guy laughin'?

question: Me.
answer: Gee, I didn't recognize you... I've never seen you laugh before. That your brother makin' the rabbit ears?

question: What is this, Twenty Questions? I'm gonna get some sleep. I suggest you do the same.
answer: Huh?

question: startled from his sleep, reflexively shoves Roger away from him. He flies into a swivel chair and goes spinning around. You damn Toon! No wonder they picked you for the patsy. Always gotta play the fool. You make me sick!
answer: Gee, you shamuses are a tough audience, but what happened to you that was so dark, lurid, embittering?

question: You wanna know? Well, since you're so goddamn curious, I'll tell ya. One of you Toons killed my brother.
answer: A Toon? Noooo.

question: Yeah, a Toon. It was the guy who killed Bambi's mother.
answer: Him? Oh, he was vile, heinous, despicable... a smear on the drafting board.

question: Yeah, everybody thought so. But me and Teddy got a kick out of Toons. All Toons. We couldn't see the bad in 'em. And when this guy was accused of knockin' over the First National Bank of Toontown, we took his case. But when we looked into it, we found out he did do it after all. We went to his house to take him in. But he was wise. He got the drop on us... literally.
answer: Safe?

question: Piano. Guy got away, disappeared into Toontown. Nobody ever saw him again.
answer: I'll get it.

question: Get away from there.
answer: Wrong number?

question: No, it's not. Dolores?
answer: on the phone in the Terminal Bar. I was hopin' you'd be there. Maroon's called here about four times. He says he's gotta talk to you tonight. He says he can help you.

question: I'll bet.
answer: Are you gonna call him, Eddie?

question: What've I got to lose? You okay, Dolores?
answer: Yeah... they closed me down for a coupla weeks.

question: That'll work out just fine. When this thing is over, I'll take you to Catalina. How does that sound?
answer: Familiar. Be careful, Eddie.

question: He CLICKS the switchhook and dials. Maroon? Whaddaya want?
answer: Have you got the will?

question: Maybe. Why?
answer: Meet me at my studio at nine o'clock. If you've got the will maybe we can stop this thing.

question: Stop what?
answer: Gee, Eddie, you're not gonna go, are ya? Maroon'll be layin' for ya at nine o'clock.

question: That's why I'll be there at 8:45.
answer: I tell you what, maybe I better come with you.

question: Forget it.
answer: You know, Eddie, I'm not as much of a chump, and a patsy, a yokel as you think.

question: How much is a shave and a haircut, Roger?
answer: Two bits.

question: I rest my case. If I don't make it back here by ten...
answer: Yeah?

question: ... I'd head for Cucamonga.
answer: Cucamonga? I don't know anybody in Cucamonga.

question: Steady, R.K., that stuff's eighteen years old.
answer: Valiant! You surprised me.

question: That was the idea. You're not too good at this, are you, R.K.?
answer: No... I'm not. I'm a cartoon maker, not a murderer.

question: Well, everybody needs a hobby.
answer: No, you gotta understand, Valiant, I had nothin' to do with Acme gettin' killed. I just wanted to sell my studio. But they wouldn't buy my property unless Acme would sell his. And he wouldn't. So I was gonna blackmail Acme with pictures of him and the rabbit's wife. But then it all went to hell. I been around Toons all my life. I can't sit around and see them all destroyed. You got the will in there, don't ya?

question: No, I don't.
answer: You tricked me, damn you!

question: Take it easy.
answer: There's no time to take it easy! You don't realize the diabolical mind we're dealing with! If I don't get that will by midnight tonight, Toontown's just gonna be land for the free...

question: sees a reflection of the gun on the glass on a movie poster on the wall. He turns. But it's too late. BANG! BANG! BANG! Maroon crumples, caught mid-sentence. Valiant dives behind the desk and draws his gun. He looks over at Maroon's dead body on the floor. And the home of the brave? grabs his black bag, climbs out of the office window and jumps off the fire escape to the lot below. slams on his brakes. The Packard goes fishtailing, finally spinning to a stop at the foot of the "Toontown" sign. picks the gun up and hefts it respectfully. Then he opens an ammo section in the wooden box. SIX TOON .38 DUM-DUM BULLETS are in velvet creases. The Toon Bullets blink to life as if awakening from a long sleep. Uh-huh. Drunk. Feelin' frisky tonight, boys? watches as a cut glass chandelier falls out of the sky and CRASHES at his feet. Valiant holsters his weapon and climbs into the Packard. He puts it in gear and pulls into the tunnel. I hate Toontown...
answer: Don't shoot, Eddie. It's me.

question: What the hell are you doin' in there?
answer: I followed you to the Maroon Studios. When I heard those shots, I thought I'd help you and investigate the inside of this trunk.

question: Steps out of the shadows behind him and aim the gun at his back. Don't move, Valiant.
answer: Well... I always figured I'd get it in Toontown.

question: I think I got him.
answer: You shot Roger.

question: That's not Roger. It's one of Doom's men. He killed R.K. Maroon.
answer: Lady, I guess I had you pegged wrong.

question: It was Doom who killed Acme, you know?
answer: Why didn't you tell me?

question: I didn't know who I could trust.
answer: We're even. By the way, I did find your husband.

question: Where is he?
answer: He's right here in the... ... car.

question: How did you get onto Doom?
answer: Marvin told me. Doom was after his land. Ne was afraid. That's why he brought me his will.

question: So where is it?
answer: When I opened up the blue envelope, all that was inside was a blank piece of paper.

question: A joker to the end.
answer: Looks like our goose is cooked, our hash is slung, our fait is accompli...

question: Lemme guess where you got that from. Tell me somethin', what'd you ever see in that guy anyway?
answer: He made me laugh.

question: Well, do you prefer to die this way or that way?
answer: Need a lift?

question: Benny.
answer: Mr. Valiant, you've made a vast improvement in the company you keep. Look, the drawbridge -- we're gonna make it.

question: I don't see any bridge.
answer: That's because you gotta draw it first.

question: The boinin', the boinin'... Oh, yeah... that's better. Roger!
answer: Benny?

question: Doom's got your wife and Valiant. He took them to the Acme factory,
answer: Let's go!

question: No matter. I don't expect the will to show up in the next fifteen minutes. By then Cloverleaf will own Toontown quite legally.
answer: So you're Cloverleaf?

question: No one person is Cloverleaf. We're a vast company with diverse interests... gasoline, tires, automobiles.
answer: turns his attention from the brick wall back to Doom. Come on, Doom. What would a company like that want with Toontown?

question: Right here where we're standing, will be the cornerstone of my idea... the cloverleaf -- an elegant cement structure that intertwines freeways.
answer: What the hell's a freeway?

question: A freeway, Mr. Valiant, is eight lanes of asphalt running uninterrupted from L.A. to Pasadena. Pasadena to Hollywood. Hollywood to Santa Monica. Someday everyone will be in cars driving happily, non-stop from one end of the L.A. Basin to another.
answer: That's what this is all about? Tell me, who's gonna use your lousy freeway? We got the Red Cars, the best public transportation in the country.

question: turns to see Doom stick his flattened thumb in his mouth. He blows, re-inflating himself. His glasses CRACK and fall off. Then his prosthetic eyeballs pop out. His teeth shatter and fall out of his mouth like china. Underneath his latex mask we can see his Toon mouth and evil red Toon eyes. Holy shit, he's a Toon!
answer: Surprised?

question: Not really. Only a Toon could think of something as goofy as that freeway idea.
answer: Is that so? Well, we'll see who's the goofy one. By the way, when I killed your brother, Teddy, I used to talk just like this.

question: You?
answer: That's right, me. Now Eddie's gonna be deady, just like Teddy. SCREAMS as the torrent hits him with a CRASH. But there's no escape for him this time. The flood of liquid envelopes him at the ankles. He dissolves into it like a melting candle.

question: Hi-ho, the Doom is dead.
answer: What the hell is that?

question: Doom.
answer: Jesus Christ... that was the Judge?
